title.rendered: What are preferred shares?  Definition, advantages and disadvantages

content.rendered:
Disadvantages of Preferred Stock

  • The fixed dividend: in the event that the company issues a larger dividend for ordinary shares in the future, this benefit would not apply because the dividend is predetermined during the issuance of preferred shares.
  • Limited liquidity: Preferred shares are long-term investments commonly purchased by institutional investors and traded on an organized trading market (rather than on a stock exchange), so their ability to convert to cash is less than that of equities. common.
  • Ownership Rights: Arguably the main drawback for holders of preferred shares is the exclusion of voting rights.

Preferred shares are a complex investment and are subject to high risks. For example, in the case of preferred shares of credit institutions, since they are not covered by the Deposit Guarantee Fund (FGD) of credit institutions, if the issuing institution were to become insolvent, the investor would lose their investment. In general, the retail investor opts for the trading of ordinary shares, which, although they also require knowledge about the operation of the stock market, offer greater liquidity.
